1-1:
1/1/1502
 Portuguese navigators reach the coast of the South American continent and name the current city of Rio de Janeiro.

1/1/1764
 In France, Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, aged 8, plays piano for the Royal Family at Versailles.

1/1/1776
 The leader of the American Revolution, George Washington presents the first national flag of the United States.

1/1/1797
 Albany replaces New York City as the capital of the state of New York.

1/1/1801
 The Act of Union, signed by Great Britain and Ireland, creates the United Kingdom.

1/1/1804
 After leading a rebellion against the French, Jean-Jacques Dessalines proclaims an independent Haiti.

1/1/1833
 The United Kingdom declares its sovereignty over the Falkland Islands.

1/1/1877
 The English Queen Victoria is proclaimed Empress of India.

1/1/1942
 26 nations sign the “Declaration of the United Nations”, expressing opposition to the Axis Forces.

1/1/1945
 France is admitted to the United Nations.
1-2:
2/1/1492
 Spain recaptures the southern city of Granada, consolidating the monarchy of Ferdinand of Aragon.

2/1/1788
 Georgia becomes the fourth state of the United States.

2/1/1839
 French photographer Louis Daguerre takes the first picture of the Moon.

2/1/1872
 Brigham Young, leader of the Mormon Church, is arrested in the United States for having married 25 women.

2/1/1935
 Bruno Hauptmann goes on trial for the kidnapping and murder of the son of aviator Charles Lindbergh.

2/1/1939
 Press is notified that Vivien Leigh, Leslie Howard and Olivia de Havilland are attached to star in Gone with the Wind....

2/1/1942
 During World War II, Japanese troops capture Manila, the capital of the Philippines.

1/2/1960
 Senator John F. Kennedy announces his candidacy for the Democratic Party nomination for President of the United States.

2/1/1987
 Ulysses Guimarães, president of the PMBD, is elected president of the Constituent Assembly.

2/1/1994
 More than 70 people die and 670 are injured during two days of fighting between factions in the Afghan capital of Kabul.
1-3:
3/1/1322
 Philip V of France dies and is succeeded by his brother, Charles IV.

3/1/1777
 During the American Revolution, General George Washington defeats British forces at the Battle of Princeton.

3/1/1857
 In France, the Archbishop of Paris is murdered by a priest.

3/1/1874
 Marshal Francisco Serrano becomes dictator of Spain.

3/1/1888
 The American Marvin C. Stone patents the drinking straw.

3/1/1920
 Babe Ruth, the greatest baseball player of all time, is sold to the New York Yankees by the Boston Red Sox.

3/1/1926
 Theodoros Pangalos proclaims himself dictator of Greece after the coup d'état that took place in the country in June.

3/1/1959
 Alaska becomes the 40th new US state.

3/1/1961
 US President Dwight D. Eisenhower cuts diplomatic ties with Cuba.

3/1/1977
 Apple Computer is founded, the industry's first personal computer.
1-4:
4/1/1717
 During the Seven Years' War, England declares war on Spain.

4/1/1908
 Mulai Hafid is proclaimed new sultan of Morocco.

4/1/1919
 Vilna, the capital of Lithuania, is captured by Soviet troops.

4/1/1932
 Peace leader Mahatma Gandhi is arrested by the British government in India.

4/1/1951
 During the Korean War, North Korean and Chinese forces capture Seoul, the capital of South Korea.

4/1/1958
 Sputnik I, the first artificial satellite launched in October 1957 by the Soviet Union, returns to Earth.

4/1/1960
 French writer Albert Camus dies in a car accident.

4/1/1965
 Poet TS Eliot dies aged 76 in London.

1/4/1971
 Dr. Melvin H. Evans becomes the first elected governor of the Virgin Islands.

4/1/1980
 US President Jimmy Carter announces a cut in wheat exports to the Soviet Union because of its invasion of Afghanistan.
1-5:
5/1/1668
 The Treaty of Madrid is signed, which establishes peace between Spain and Portugal, putting an end to the Wars of Restoration.

5/1/1757
 Jean-Francois Damiens attempts to assassinate Louis XV of France. He was subsequently executed for having attempted to kill the monarch.

5/1/1762
 Elizabeth, Empress of Russia, dies and is succeeded by her nephew, Peter III.

1/5/1867
 The first urban train in Latin America is inaugurated in Recife – the "Maxabomba".

5/1/1907
 Enacted in Brazil the Adolpho Gordo Law, which authorizes the creation of professional unions.

1/5/1914
 Henry Ford, head of the Ford Motor Company, sets his employees a minimum daily wage of $5.

5/1/1925
 Nellie Taylor Ross takes over the governorship of the state of Wyoming. She is the first woman to be elected governor in the United States.

5/1/1947
 Rally in Anhangabaú seals the support of the PCB to Adhemar de Barros for the government of São Paulo.

5/1/1955
 François Mitterrand, the French Minister of the Interior, proposes the integration of Algeria into France.

5/1/1956
 Film actress Grace Kelly announces her engagement to the Prince of Monaco, Ranier III.
1-6:
6/1/1066
 Harald is crowned King of England after the death of his brother-in-law, Edward. He is the country's last Anglo-Saxon king.

6/1/1099
 Henry V, second son of Henry IV, is crowned King of Germany.

6/1/1535
 The city of Lima, Peru, is founded by the Spanish conqueror Francisco Pizarro.

6/1/1759
 The father of American independence and first president of the United States, George Washington marries Martha Dandridge Custis.

6/1/1838
 Samuel FB Morse gives a public demonstration of his invention - the telegraph - in the US state of New Jersey.

6/1/1919
 Theodore Roosevelt, 26th US president, whose administration was marked by an interventionist foreign policy, dies.

6/1/1929
 King Alexander of Yugoslavia abolishes the constitution, dissolves the government, and establishes a monarchical dictatorship in the country.

1/6/1945
 George Herbert Walker Bush, future President of the United States, marries Barbara Pierce in New York.

6/1/1950
 Great Britain formally recognizes the government of Communist China.

6/1/1952
 The cartoon “Peanuts”, featuring the characters Charlie Brown and Snoopy, is released by Charles Schulz.
1-7:
7/1/1610
 Astronomer Galileo Galilei sights four moons of the planet Jupiter.

7/1/1782
 In Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, “The Bank of North America”, the first commercial bank in the States opens.

7/1/1789
 The first presidential elections take place in the United States.

7/1/1895
 Korea declares its independence from China.

7/1/1927
 Transatlantic telephone service between New York and London opens.

7/1/1953
 US President Harry Truman announces that the United States had developed the hydrogen bomb.

7/1/1959
 The United States recognizes the new government of Cuba led by Fidel Castro.

7/1/1979
 Vietnamese troops capture the Cambodian city of Phnom Penh and overthrow the Khmer Rouge government.

7/1/1987
 US government sources reveal that US per capita debt has risen to $10,047.

7/1/1989
 Japanese Emperor Hirohito dies aged 87, and is succeeded by Prince Akihito.
1-8:
8/1/1642
 Astronomer Galileo Galilei dies in Arcetri, Italy.

8/1/1815
 American troops, led by General Andrew Jackson, defeat the British in the Battle of New Orleans and win the War of 1812.

8/1/1918
 US President Woodrow Wilson presents to Congress a plan to maintain world peace after World War I.

8/1/1925
 Russian composer Igor Stravinsky gives his first concert in the United States; he conducts the New York Philharmonic Orchestra.

8/1/1926
 Abdul Azziz ibn Saud becomes king of a nation he names Saudi Arabia.

8/1/1958
 At the age of 14, Bobby Fisher wins the United States Chess Championship for the first time.

8/1/1959
 Charles de Gaulle becomes the first president of the French Fifth Republic.

1/8/1964
 Democratic President Lyndon Johnson declares a 'War on Poverty' in the United States.

8/1/1966
 Charles de Gaulle begins his second term as President of France.

8/1/1971
 Sir Geoffrey Jackson, the British Ambassador to Uruguay, is kidnapped by Tupamaro guerrillas.
1-9:
9/1/1788
 Connecticut ratifies the United States Constitution and becomes the fifth state of the new nation.

9/1/1875
 Alfonso XII arrives in Barcelona and is proclaimed King of Spain.

9/1/1878
 Victor Emmanuel dies and is succeeded as King of Italy by Umberto I.

9/1/1951
 In New York, the headquarters of the United Nations opens.

9/1/1957
 Anthony Eden resigns as Prime Minister of Great Britain, citing health reasons.

9/1/1962
 Japan signs a treaty, agreeing to pay $290 million to the United States for aid received after World War II.

9/1/1980
 In Saudi Arabia, 63 Muslim fanatics are beheaded for besieging the Grand Mosque in Mecca in November 1979.

9/1/1984
 Jordan's parliament convenes for the first time in ten years.

9/1/1996
 Chechen rebels capture 2000 Russians and threaten to kill them if their demands are not accepted by the Russian government.
1-10:
10/1/1645
 William Laud, Archbishop of Canterbury, is accused of treason and beheaded.

1/10/1920
 The League of Nations is established when the Treaty of Versailles comes into effect.

1/10/1928
 The Soviet Union, under the command of Joseph Stalin, orders the exile of revolutionary leader Leon Trotsky.

1/10/1942
 The 21-year-old famous actor Mickey Rooney marries a previously little-known 19-year-old actress named Ava Gardner.

1/10/1946
 The League of Nations is officially replaced by the United Nations when the first meeting of the General Assembly takes place in London.

10/1/1957
 Harold Macmillan becomes Britain's new Prime Minister the day after the resignation of Sir Anthony Eden.

1/10/1967
 Edward W. Brooke, representing the state of Massachusetts, is the first black to enter the United States Senate.

10/1/1969
 Sweden becomes the first Western country to establish relations with North Vietnam.

1/10/1990
 China announces the end of martial law, and claims that by preventing democratic demonstrations, it saved the country from the 'abyss of misery'.

1/10/1994
 President Bill Clinton announces that Ukraine has agreed to give up its nuclear arsenal – the third largest in the world.
1-11:
11/1/1814
 Joachim Murat, King of Naples, breaks alliance with Napoleon and forms an alliance with Austria.

1/11/1922
 Leonard Thompson, a 14-year-old Canadian boy, is the first person to be treated for diabetes with insulin.

1/11/1935
 Amelia Earhart Putnam becomes first person to fly solo from Hawaii to California.

1/11/1942
 During World War II, Japan declares war on the Netherlands.

11/1/1946
 Albania becomes a People's Republic after the overthrow of King Zog.

1/11/1976
 A three-man military junta seizes power from President Guillermo Rodriguez Lara in Ecuador.

1/11/1977
 France causes controversy by freeing Abu Daoud, a Palestinian suspected of the massacre of Israeli athletes at the 1972 Olympics.

1/11/1991
 Soviet troops storm buildings in Vilna, capital of Lithuania, to prevent an independence movement in the country.

1/11/1994
 The Irish government announces the end of censorship of the terrorist movement IRA and its political wing, Sinn Fein.

1/11/1996
 The Prime Minister of Italy, Lamberto Dini, announces his resignation.
1-12:
1/12/1773
 In the US state of South Carolina, the first public museum in the Americas is founded.

1/12/1816
 France decrees that the Bonaparte family must be banished from the country forever.

1/12/1915
 The US Congress rejects the proposal to grant the right to vote to the women of the country.

1/12/1932
 Hattie W. Caraway, a Democrat representing the state of Arkansas, becomes the first woman to be elected to the US Senate.

1/12/1942
 During World War II, the Japanese army captures the capital of Malaysia.

1/12/1945
 During World War II, Soviet troops launch a major offensive against the Germans in Eastern Europe.

1/12/1950
 The Soviet Union re-introduces the death penalty in the country, for crimes of treason, espionage and sabotage.

1/12/1964
 A month after Zanzibar becomes independent, the government is overthrown in a coup d'état.

1/12/1966
 President Lyndon Johnson declares that US troops must remain in Vietnam until the country's communist forces are defeated.

1/12/1974
 The countries of Libya and Tunisia announce that they would be joining under the name of “Islamic Arab Republic”.
1-13:
13/1/1893
 The British Independent Labor Party, forerunner of today's Labor Party, meets for the first time.

1/13/1898
 The French author Emile Zola publishes the letter “J'Accuse”, in which he denounces the French government of covering up the injustice of the Dreyfus affair.

1/13/1915
 The city of Avezzano, in central Italy, is hit by an earthquake, resulting in 30,000 deaths.

1/13/1941
 James Joyce, considered the best Irish writer, dies in Zurich, Switzerland at the age of 58.

1/13/1942
 Representatives of the Allied forces meet in London and declare that they will punish war criminals after the end of the world conflict.

1/13/1964
 The producer Capitol releases in the United States the new Beatles releases: “I Want to Hold Your Hand” and “I Saw Her Standing There”.

1/13/1972
 In the African country of Ghana, a military coup led by Colonel IK Acheampong overthrows Prime Minister KA Busia.

1/13/1976
 Great Britain requests from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) a credit of 1 billion pounds.

1/13/1989
 Computers in Great Britain hit by virus “Friday the 13th”.

1/13/1992
 Japan apologizes to thousands of Korean women who were used as sex slaves during World War II.
1-14:
1/14/1742
 English astronomer Edmond Halley, who observed the comet that bears his name, dies at the age of 85.

1/14/1784
 The United States ratifies a peace treaty with England ending the American Revolution.

14/1/1858
 An Italian revolutionary, Felice Orsini throws bombs in an attempt to assassinate Napoleon III in Paris, but the Emperor is unharmed.

1/14/1866
 Peru, dissatisfied with the terms of the peace treaty recognizing its independence in 1865, declares war on Spain.

1/14/1900
 Giacomo Pucini's new opera – Tosca – premieres in Rome.

1/14/1907
 Hundreds die when an earthquake strikes Kingston, the capital of Jamaica.

1/14/1943
 US President Roosevelt and British Prime Minister Churchill begin a war conference in Casablanca.

1/14/1953
 Marshal Tito is elected first president of the Republic of Yugoslavia.

1/14/1954
 Actress Marilyn Monroe, aged 29, marries baseball star Joe DiMaggio in San Francisco.

1/14/1965
 The Prime Ministers of Ireland and Northern Ireland meet for the first time in 43 years.
1-15:
1/15/1535
 In England, King Henry VIII becomes supreme leader of the Church.

1/15/1559
 English Queen Elizabeth I is crowned at Westminster Abbey.

1/15/1777
 The people of Vermont declare their independence from England. The small republic becomes a US state in 1791.

1/15/1972
 Margaret II is proclaimed Queen of Denmark following the death of her father, Frederick IX.

1/15/1973
 Golda Meir is the first Israeli leader to be received by the Pope.

1/15/1973
 US President Richard Nixon orders an end to military strikes against North Vietnam.

1/15/1976
 Sara Jane Moore is sentenced to life in prison for the attempted assassination of President Gerald Ford in San Francisco.

1/15/1990
 Bulgaria's parliament officially ends the Communist Party's political monopoly in the country.

1/15/1992

15/1/1996
 The Socialist Prime Minister of Greece, Andréas Papandreou, resigns due to health reasons.
1-16:
1/16/1547
 Ivan IV (Ivan the Terrible) is crowned first Tsar of Russia. His notorious reign was marked by the execution of over 3000 people.

16/1/1556
 Charles I of Spain is succeeded by his son Felipe II.

1/16/1920

1/16/1944
 US General Dwight D. Eisenhower assumes command of Allied forces in London.

1/16/1947
 Vincent Auriol is elected President of France, the fifth President of the Fourth Republic.

1/16/1979
 Shah of Iran leaves country after being expelled by Ayatollah Khomeini.

1/16/1979
 An earthquake, measuring 7 on the Richter scale, strikes Iran, resulting in hundreds of deaths.

1/16/1980
 The government of Great Britain announces the establishment of diplomatic relations with Chile, broken off in 1976.

1/16/1991
 Allied forces, led by the United States, begin a military offensive against Iraq. It is the beginning of the Gulf War.

1/16/1992
 Salvadoran government officials and rebel leaders sign a peace pact, ending the country's 12-year civil war.
1-17:
1/17/1893
 Rutherford B. Hayes, 19th President of the United States, dies at age 70 in Fremont, Ohio.

1/17/1931
 A hunger march programmed by the Brazilian Communist Party (PCB) in Rio de Janeiro is repressed.

1/17/1945
 During World War II, Soviet and Polish forces liberate Warsaw, the capital of Poland.

1/17/1945
 Swedish diplomat Raoul Wallenberg, who saved tens of thousands of Jews during World War II, disappears in Hungary.

1/17/1946
 The United Nations Security Council holds its first conference.

1/17/1983

1/17/1986

1/17/1994
 An earthquake measuring 6.7 on the Richter scale strikes California, causing the deaths of 61 people and damages of $20 billion.

1/17/1995
 More than 6000 people are killed when an earthquake, measuring 7.2 on the Richter scale, strikes central Japan.
1-18:
1/18/1778
 The English navigator, Captain James Cook, discovers the islands of Hawaii, which he nicknames “Sandwich Islands”.

1/18/1788
 The first English settlers arrive in Australia to establish a colony for English convicts.

1/18/1862
 John Tyler, 10th President of the United States, dies in Richmond, Virginia, aged 71.

1/18/1919
 The Versailles peace conference that officially ended World War I begins.

1/18/1943
 During World War II, the Soviet Union announces that it has managed to break through the Nazi siege imposed on the city of Leningrad.

1/18/1984
 Paulo Maluf launches his candidacy for the presidency of the Republic.

1/18/1990
 Marion Barry, the mayor of Washington DC, the US capital, is arrested for drug possession.

1/18/1991
 The international music festival, “Rock in Rio” starts in Rio de Janeiro.

1/18/1991
 During the Gulf War, Iraq launches eight missiles at Israel, with the aim of forcing the Jewish state into the conflict.

1/18/1993
 The Martin Luther King Jr. Holiday, in memory of the great civil rights leader, is observed in all 50 US states.
1-19:
1/19/1899
 Great Britain and Egypt establish joint control over the African country of Sudan.

1/19/1937
 Howard Hughes sets a transcontinental flight record by flying from Los Angeles to New York in 7 hours and 28 minutes.

1/19/1938
 Remaining faithful from Caldeirão are attacked by the police in Pau de Colher, Bahia, resulting in 400 deaths.

1/19/1944
 During World War II, the British air force drops 2300 tons of bombs on the German capital of Berlin.

1/19/1949
 The salary of the President of the United States increases from $75,000 to $100,000 a year.

1/19/1966
 Indira Gandhi is elected Prime Minister of India.

1/19/1979
 President João Figueiredo appoints Francelino Pereira as president of Arena (Aliança Renovadora Nacional).

1/19/1981
 The United States and Iran sign an agreement resulting in the release of 52 Americans held hostage for more than 14 months.

1/19/1982
 Elis Regina dies at the age of 36. A singer from Rio Grande do Sul, she was one of the most important performers of the post-bossa nova generation in the country.

1/19/1983
 South Africa returns to rule Namibia after five years of semi-autonomous government in the country.
1-20:
20/1/1841
 The island of Hong Kong is ceded by China to Great Britain. But the agreement between the two countries establishes that Hong Kong will return to Chinese control in July 1997.

20/1/1890
 The National Anthem of Brazil, composed by Francisco Manuel da Silva, is made official.

20/1/1936
 King George V of Great Britain dies, and is succeeded by Edward VIII.

20/1/1941
 The Ministry of Aeronautics is founded in Brazil.

1/20/1942
 Nazi officials meet and decide to implement the “Final Solution to the Jewish Problem”: the extermination of all Jews in Europe.

1/20/1951
 Tupi TV in Rio de Janeiro is inaugurated.

1/20/1961
 John F. Kennedy takes office as the 35th President of the United States.

1/20/1971
 Rubens Paiva, impeached deputy, is arrested for repression in Rio de Janeiro and disappears.

1/20/1976
 President Ernesto Geisel removes the commander of the Second Army in reaction to the crisis caused by the deaths of journalist Vladimir Herzog and worker Manuel Fiel Filho, both PCB militants.

20/1/1977
 The International Airport of Rio de Janeiro is inaugurated.
1-21:
21/1/1793
 King Louis XVI of France is convicted of treason and guillotined. He had reigned France since 1774 and remained king of the country for three years after the French Revolution of 1789.

21/1/1846
 The first edition of the English newspaper “London Daily News” is published.

1/21/1906
 A police pact between Brazil, Argentina, and Uruguay is signed against the anarchist movement in the three countries. This cooperation system was a precursor to Operation Condor – an agreement between the dictatorial regimes of Chile, Argentina, Uruguay, Paraguay and Bolivia, to persecute their opponents in the 70s and 80s.

1/21/1924
 Soviet leader and Russian revolutionary, Vladimir Ilyich Lenin, dies aged 54 from a cerebral hemorrhage. He led the Bolsheviks in the October Revolution of 1917, becoming leader of newly established communist Russia.

1/21/1936
 In Great Britain, Edward VIII is proclaimed King following the death of his father, George V. He remained King until December 1936, when he abdicated the throne and was succeeded by George VI.

1/21/1950
 George Orwell (Eric Blair), author of literary classics such as “1984” and “The Triumph of the Pigs” dies in London of tuberculosis at the age of 46.

1/21/1954
 The first atomic submarine, the USS Nautilus, is launched in Groton, Connecticut.

1/21/1965
 Hassan Ali Mansur, Prime Minister of Persia – now Iran – is assassinated.

1/21/1966
 In England, the “Beatle” George Harrison marries Patrícia (Patty) Anne Boyd. They had met during the filming of the movie “Beatles - Os Reis do Iê-Iê-Iê” (A Hard Day's Night, 1964).

1/21/1976
 Western newspapers, including the English “Financial Times” and the American “The New York Times” are sold in the Soviet Union for the first time.
1-22:
1/22/1840
 The first British settlers arrive in Port Nicholson, New Zealand.

1/22/1891
 Benjamin Constant, politician and military man from Rio de Janeiro, one of the founders of the Republic and author of the motto Order and Progress of the Brazilian flag, dies at the age of 54 in Rio de Janeiro.

22/1/1901
 Queen Victoria of England dies, passing away after 63 years of reign.

1/22/1917
 US President Woodrow Wilson calls for an end to the war in Europe, calling for a 'peace without victory'. Despite his opposition to the conflict, the United States would enter World War I in April of the same year .

1/22/1942
 Senai (National Service for Industrial Learning), an entity governed by private law, is created.

1/22/1945
 The first Brazilian Congress of Writers takes place in Rio de Janeiro. The participants ask for complete freedom of expression in the country and direct elections for president.

1/22/1953
 “The Salem Witches”, a drama by Arthur Miller about the persecution of women in Massachusetts accused of being witches, opens on Broadway. suspected communists in the entertainment world, led by US government officials.

22/1/1973
 In a historic and controversial legal decision, called 'Roe versus Wade', the US Supreme Court legalizes abortion in the United States.

1/22/1973
 Former US President Lyndon Johnson dies at the age of 64. Johnson had been John F. Kennedy's vice president, and assumed leadership of the country after the president's assassination. of his term, he did not run for re-election, because of the mass protests in the country due to the Vietnam War.

1/22/1995
 Rose Fitzgerald Kennedy, Kennedy family matriarch and mother of former President John F. Kennedy and Senator Robert Kennedy, dies in Hyannis Port, Massachusetts, aged 104.
1-23:
1/23/1789
 Georgetown College, now famous Georgetown University in Washington DC, is established as the first Catholic college in the United States.

1/23/1806
 William Pitt, Prime Minister of Great Britain dies aged 46. At the age of 24, he had become the youngest Prime Minister in the history of the country.

1/23/1845
 Congress decides that all national elections must be held on the Tuesday after the first Monday in November.

1/23/1849
 Englishwoman Elizabeth Blackwell becomes the first woman in the United States to receive a degree from a medical school at the Medical Institution of Geneva in New York.

23/1/1868
 Companhia Paulistana de Estradas de Ferro is founded by coffee producers.

1/23/1907
 Charles Curtis, representing the state of Kansas, begins his term in the United States Senate. He is the first Indian to reach that political position. In 1929, he resigned to become Vice President of the United States under the leadership of Herbert Hoover.

23/1/1937
 The trial of 17 communist leaders accused of involvement in a plot led by Leon Trotsky to overthrow the Russian government begins in Moscow. Such accusations were purposely invented by the dictator Joseph Stalin who wanted to eliminate his political opponents.

23/1/1950
 The Knesset, the Israeli parliament, passes a resolution that proclaims Jerusalem as the capital of the state of Israel.

23/1/1968
 North Korea captures a US navy ship, the 'Pueblo'. The North Koreans claimed that the ship had been sent on a spy mission. The US crew were only released 11 months ago after.

1/23/1973
 In Kingston, Jamaica, George Foreman defeats Joe Frazier, and becomes heavyweight boxing champion of the world.
1-24:
1/24/1943
 During World War II, US President Franklin D. Roosevelt and British Prime Minister Winston Churchill close a war conference in Casablanca, Morocco.

24/1/1960
 An insurrection begins in Algeria against the French colonization of the country.

1/24/1965
 Winston Churchill, British statesman and Prime Minister and one of the leaders of the Allied Forces during World War II, dies in London at the age of 90.

24/1/1966
 Indira Gandhi, daughter of Nehru, takes over as Prime Minister of India after the death of Sri Shastri.

1/24/1967
 The 1967 Constitution is imposed by the Brazilian military regime on Congress. Despite approving the new military Constitution, Congress made two reservations: the prohibition of closing Congress and the creation of parliamentary immunity.

24/1/1969
 Fascist dictator Francisco Franco declares martial law in Spain, after public demonstrations, in which 300 people were arrested.

1/24/1972
 A Japanese soldier, Shoichi Yokoi, is found on the island of Guam. He spent 28 years in the jungle, believing that World War II was not over yet.

1/24/1980
 “Calabar – O Elogio da Traição”, a play by Chico Buarque and Rui Guerra is released by the Brazilian censorship. “Calabar”, written during the military dictatorship, is a historical allegory that takes place at the time of the Dutch invasions in Pernambuco in the 17th century. The play portrays the issue of loyalty and betrayal, in an obvious allusion to the political reality of Brazil in the period in which it was written.

1/24/1987
 The American Jesse Turner, a computing professor at the University of Beirut, Lebanon, is kidnapped by an Islamic fundamentalist group. He is only released in October 1991.

1/24/1990
 President Fernando Collor de Mello begins a 20-day tour of the United States, Japan, the Soviet Union, and other Western European countries.
1-25:
25/1/1533
 The English King Henry VIII secretly marries Anne Boleyn. Their daughter was later crowned Queen Elizabeth I.

25/1/1881
 The famous Russian author Fyodor Dostoyevsky passes away a few days after suffering a hemorrhage. His last words were, 'Do not hold me. My time has come. I must die'. Dostoyevsky had written the classic 'Crime and Punishment'.

1/25/1915
 In New York, Alexander Graham Bell speaks by telephone with his assistant in California. It is the beginning of transcontinental telephone service in the United States.

1/25/1919
 Soon after World War I, the League of Nations is founded, the forerunner of the United Nations.

1/25/1924
 The first Winter Olympics begins in Chamonix, France.

25/1/1947
 The notorious American gangster, Al Capone, dies of syphilis at the age of 48 in Miami Beach, Florida. Al Capone, leader of organized crime in the city of Chicago, had been arrested for tax evasion.

1/25/1954
 The city of São Paulo completes 400 years. The celebration party includes the inauguration of Ibirapuera Park and the Sé Cathedral, under construction since 1913.

1/25/1955
 The leadership of the Soviet Union officially declares the end of the country's state of war with Germany.

1/25/1961
 The Disney cartoon “One Hundred and One Dalmatians” is released in North American theaters. The film took three years to complete and cost $4 million. It was a huge box office success.

26/1/1784

26/1/1827
 Peru announces the end of its union with Colombia and declares its independence.

1/26/1838
 The Brazilian Historical and Geographical Institute is founded in Rio de Janeiro.

26/1/1841

 Iraq, accusing Kuwait of conspiring to harm its economy through overproduction of oil, deploys tens of thousands of troops and hundreds of tanks along the Iraq-Kuwait border.

 Ulysses S. Grant becomes the first American officer to be promoted to the position of General of the United States Army.

 At the Guararapes airport, in Pernambuco, there is a failed bomb attack against Costa e Silva.

 President Geisel eliminates party programs in free time on TV.

 New York becomes the 11th state to ratify the US Constitution.

 First automobile race in São Paulo.

 PTB Convention ratifies the candidacy of Getúlio Vargas for the presidency.

 Thomas Cromwell, adviser to King Henry VIII of England, is convicted of treason and executed.

 The Bank of England is founded by the English Parliament.

 Maximilien Robespierre, the main architect of the Reign of Terror of the French Revolution, is deposed and arrested by the National Convention.  Belarus declares its independence from the Soviet Union.

 Peru declares its independence from Spain.

 Princess Isabel is sworn in by the Senate as heir presumptive to the throne.

 The artist Vincent Van Gogh dies in France, aged 37, two days after shooting himself in the chest.
